Occupancy is  quantitative metric used to depict -actin density with higher values indicating  denser - actin network (Higaki et al., 2010b). Compared with controls, occupancy of -actin in roots treated with 100 nM LatB, 500 nM eBL, and    eBL was lower. Surprisingly, -actin occupancy was signi cantly higher in roots treated with    eBL compared to control roots (Figure 2B). Taken together, our results show that eBL modi es -actin organization in maize roots by causing  signi cant reduction in density. However, unlike roots treated with LatB, which showed more widespread disruption of -actin, roots treated with eBL required higher concentrations (.. ) to detect distinct qualitative and quantitative effects on -actin structure. Even at this higher concentration, impacts on -actin appeared to be localized to random regions of the root (Figure 2A). Another metric that we used to quantify eBL effects on -actin structure is skewness, which measures the degree of asymmetry of  uorescence intensity distribution. Skewness has been shown to be  good indicator of -actin bundling (Higaki et al., 2010a). We found that while LatB treatment resulted in  small but signi cant increase in bundling, eBL at all concentrations, did not (Figure 2C). Lifeact-mGFP and GFP-ABD2-GFP Reporters Decorate Extensive -Actin Networks in Living . truncatula Seedlings Our studies on chemically- xed roots of . mays, support the hypothesis that the effects of eBL on root gravitropism and autotropic straightening on  - clinostat are due to disruptions in normal actin function (Figures  and ). However, the results indicate that eBL only had modest effects on overall -actin organization based on qualitative and quantitative analyses of chemically- xed . mays roots (Figures 2A ). Therefore, we next asked if effects of eBL on -actin would be more obvious in living roots. To address this question, transgenic . truncatula plants that expressed two live cell -actin reporters (Lifeact-mGFP and GFP-ABD2-GFP) under the control of the ubiquitin 10 (UBQ10) promoter were generated (Wang et al., 2008; Vidali et al., 2009; Dyachok et al., 2014; Sparks et al., 2016). Before using the lines for clinorotation assays, we  rst examined the quality of -actin labeling in seedling roots. We found that Lifeact-mGFP and GFP-ABD2-GFP decorated extensive -actin networks in various developmental regions of seedling roots. Distinct - actin arrays were present in border cells, meristematic cells and cells in the transition/elongation zone. Similar to previous reports in . thaliana, both Lifeact-mGFP and GFP-ABD2- GFP reporters labeled end walls and phragmoplasts in the meristem, and random and longitudinal -actin cables in the elongation zone of . truncatula seedling roots (Figure 3A). In agreement with previously published work with  xed and living roots, both reporters did not label distinct -actin networks in the columella despite the presence of clear -actin bundles in the peripheral cap and border cells. Only diffuse  uorescence was observed in the central columella of both reporter lines (Figure 3A; Baluska et al., 1997; Blanca or, 2013). Lifeact-mGFP and GFP-ABD2-GFP also labeled extensive -actin arrays in growing root hairs that were reminiscent of -actin organization in . thaliana lines expressing these two reporters (Figure 3B; Dyachok et al., 2014; Sparks et al., 2016). Moreover, other cell types in transgenic lines expressing GFP-ABD2-GFP and Lifeact- mGFP including guard cells, minor leaf veins and epidermal cells in nodules exhibited dense -actin arrays (Figures 3C ). Although primary root length and growth rate of -day-old . truncatula seedlings expressing Lifeact-mGFP and GFP-ABD2- GFP were similar to wild type (Figures 3F, ), dry weights of the same lines at 28 days were lower compared to wild type (Figures 3H, ). Epi-Brassinolide Triggers Enhanced Root Curvature Responses in . truncatula on  Clinostat, But Only Had Mild Effects on -Actin Organization We next asked if eBL could elicit similar enhancement of root curvature responses in . truncatula on  clinostat that was previously observed in . mays roots (Figure ). As  mM eBL was required to observe clear effects on -actin in chemically-  xed . mays roots (Figure ), we used the same concentration for the . truncatula clinostat assays. Furthermore, we focused our clinostat assays on lines expressing GFP-ABD2-GFP. The GFP-ABD2-GFP lines were chosen for our root clinostat assays because -actin in the transition and elongation zone was  ner and less bundled compared to Lifeact-mGFP lines, an observation consistent with previous work on . thaliana (Dyachok et al., 2014). Consistent with previous reports, LatB- treated . truncatula roots expressing GFP-ABD2-GFP exhibited enhanced curvature on  clinostat (Figures 4A, ; Hou et al., 2003). Like in . mays roots, eBL treatment caused . truncatula roots to curve strongly on  clinostat (Figures 4A, ). Although, enhanced curvature on  clinostat was observed in LatB- and eBL-treated . truncatula roots, the  nal average curvature was less than that observed in . mays (Compare Figure  and Figure ). Having established that . truncatula roots expressing the GFP-ABD2-GFP -actin reporter exhibited enhanced curvature on  clinostat, we then asked if -actin organization in living roots was modi ed by eBL. We focused our analyses on root cells within the transition and elongation zone. Consistent with observations in chemically- xed . mays roots, -actin in . truncatula roots expressing UBQ10:GFP-ABD2-GFP was clearly disrupted after treatment with 100 nM LatB. While root epidermal cells in the elongation zone of untreated roots had extensive cortical -actin networks, -actin in the same region after   exposure to 100 nM LatB were less dense and fragmented (Figure 5A). Moreover, -actin in live . truncatula roots treated with LatB had lower occupancy values, which corroborated results with chemically  xed . mays roots (Figure 5B). Experiments with eBL were less conclusive, de Bang et al. Brassinosteroids Modulate Root Autotropism Frontiers in Plant Science | www.frontiersin.org February 2020 | Volume 11 | Article

particularly with regard to the impact on -actin density. Surprisingly, -actin in roots treated with    eBL had intact cortical -actin networks that were qualitatively similar to untreated roots (Figure 5A). Quantitative analysis showed that -actin occupancy values were consistent with the observation that    eBL had no signi cant effects on -actin density in living roots (Figure 5B). Furthermore, while -actin skewness increased in LatB-treated roots, this metric was not affected by    eBL (Figure 5C). Next, we asked if eBL had other measurable quantitative impacts on -actin organization in living . truncatula roots. For this analysis, the degree of orientation of -actin in root cell images was analyzed using  metric called eccentricity. Lower eccentricity values indicate  more disordered -actin network. Modi ed cortical -actin eccentricity was reported in Physcomitrella patens ROP4 RNA interference (RNAi) lines (Burkart et al., 2015). Using metrics developed by Burkhart et al. (2015), we found that -actin in living . truncatula roots treated with 100 nM LatB and    eBL had signi cantly lower eccentricity values than -actin in untreated roots. This result indicated that both LatB and eBL treatments led to more disordered -actin (Figure 5D). Epi-Brassinolide Inhibits Global -Actin Dynamics in Etiolated Hypocotyls of Living . truncatula Seedlings Because actin function is de ned not only by overall organization within cells, but also by dynamics (Staiger et al., 2009; Burkart et al., 2015), the effects of eBL on -actin dynamics were analyzed. For these experiments, epidermal cells of etiolated barrel medic seedlings expressing UBQ10:Lifeact-mGFP were used for analyzing -actin dynamics. We used lines expressing UBQ10:Lifeact-mGFP for these analyses because the -actin arrays in hypocotyls of these lines were more readily visualized than those expressing UBQ10:GFP-ABD2-GFP. Roots were not used for this analysis because they grew out of the  eld of view within the desired  min period required for global actin dynamics analysis. Furthermore, the thick roots from . truncatula were dif cult to keep in the same focal plane during imaging, which complicated the interpretation of results. Cortical -actin in . truncatula hypocotyls were captured every second for  min and movies were used to quantify global changes in -actin following the metrics developed by Vidali et al. (2010) (Supplemental Movies S1 and S2). These metrics included pixel difference values that capture intensity differences between images every second, and correlation coef cients that indicate the degree of change (Figures 6A, ). larger difference between pixels over time and  steeper decay in the correlation coef cient indicated  more dynamic -actin network (Vidali et al., 2010; Dyachok et al., 2014; Burkart et al., 2015). The - actin network in epidermal cells of eBL-treated etiolated . truncatula hypocotyls had lower intensity difference values and  more gradual decay of the correlation coef cient compared to solvent control seedlings (Figures 6C, ). Taken together, these data imply that eBL treatment suppressed -actin dynamics in etiolated . truncatula hypocotyls. DISCUSSION In this paper,  slowly-rotating - clinostat was used to gain additional insights into actin-mediated regulation of directional root growth. These experiments showed that brassinosteroids were involved in modulating directional root growth, in part, by modifying the organization and dynamics of the actin cytoskeleton. This conclusion was based on the observation that exogenous application of eBL and LatB triggered similar enhanced root gravitropism and ampli ed root coiling on  clinostat (Figure ). The curvature responses of roots treated with eBL and LatB during continuous gravistimulation and on  clinostat are reminiscent of the behavior of in orescence stems of . thaliana myosin XI and actin8 mutants (Kato et al., 2010; Okamoto et al., 2015; Talts et al., 2016). The hyperbending of in orescence stems of myosin and actin . thaliana mutants was proposed to be the result of inhibited autotropism. aberrant acto-myosin system in  ber cells, it was proposed that the stems could no longer perceive their posture to initiate  straightening response (Okamoto et al., 2015).

aberrant acto-myosin system in  ber cells, it was proposed that the stems could no longer perceive their posture to initiate  straightening response (Okamoto et al., 2015). Here, we propose that  similar mechanism may be operating in roots, and that eBL is  component of the root organ straightening response through its impacts on -actin. Most of the studies implicating the actin cytoskeleton in gravitropism have emphasized its role in the gravity perception phase (Blanca or, 2013; Su et al., 2017). In gravity sensing cells such as the columella, actin has been proposed to interact with amyloplasts to facilitate conversion of the physical gravity signal to  biochemical signal (Zheng et al., 2015). Because actin inhibitors such as LatB or mutations to genes encoding actin itself led to stronger root gravitropic curvature (Yamamoto and Kiss, 2002; Hou et al., 2003; Kato et al., 2010; Lanza et al., 2012), it was proposed that the unrestrained sedimentation of amyloplasts may amplify the gravity sensing signal leading to  more robust graviresponse (Blanca or, 2013). However, work on . thaliana myosin XI mutants (Okamoto et al., 2015) and results presented here, suggest  more prominent role for actin in the graviresponse phase, and more speci cally in the autotropic straightening response that enables plant organs to correct their orientation (Stankovic et al., 1998a; Stankovi  et al., 1998b). Furthermore, given the dif culties in obtaining clear images of -actin in the columella (Figure ), we cannot rule out the possibility that  secondary mechanism of gravity sensing in the root transition zone might be affected by LatB (Wolverton et al., 2002). number of studies have implicated eBL in directional root growth control. For instance, eBL application mirrored the enhanced root waving and gravitropism of . thaliana actin2 mutants and caused disruptions in -actin con gurations in wild type (Lanza et al., 2012). Enhanced root gravitropism was also observed in wild-type . thaliana roots treated with eBL and this process was proposed to be mediated by ROP2-dependent modi cation of -actin assembly and disassembly (Li et al., 2005). While our results expand on these previous observations, experiments with  clinostat implicated eBL as  potential regulator of autotropism, and like previous results with LatB-treated roots, provide an alternative explanation of why this hormone has an apparent promotive effect on gravitropism. Although previous studies have shown that eBL modi es - actin organization in . thaliana roots (Lanza et al., 2012), we found that eBL effects on -actin organization in  xed . mays FIGURE  | -actin organization in epidermal cells of living . truncatula roots expressing UBQ10:GFP-ABD2-GFP after   exposure to LatB or eBL. () Representative single confocal optical section images of cells in the elongation zone. Note the reduced  uorescence and extensive fragmentation of -actin in cells treated with LatB but not with eBL. The two right most panels show variable effects of eBL on -actin organization. ( ) Combined box and scatter plots showing quantitative analysis of -actin occupancy (density), skewness (bundling) and eccentricity in root cells of the transition/elongation zone. Unlike LatB-treatment, no signi cant differences between eBL and solvent controls were detected with regard to -actin occupancy () and skewness (). However,  signi cant difference was observed between eBL and solvent controls with regard to the eccentricity metric, which refers to alignment of -actin (). Asterisks (*) refers to individual data points and + mark outliers. Statistical signi cance was determined by one-way ANOVA. Bars are means ( > 50 cells)   .. Different letters indicate signi cant differences among means ( < .05, Tukey  test). Scale bar = 20 mm. de Bang et al. roots and living . truncatula roots were not as pronounced and consistent as those induced by LatB. Higher concentrations of eBL were needed to elicit distinct qualitative and quantitative changes in -actin in both chemically- xed . mays roots and living . truncatula roots. In fact, it was surprising to  nd that    eBL led to increased -actin occupancy values compared to controls, while concentrations lower (500 nM) or higher (  ) than    led to reduced values (Figure 2B). Moreover, -actin occupancy and bundling in living roots treated with    eBL was not different from untreated controls (Figures 5B, ). LatB- treatment on the other hand, led to an increase in -actin bundling, which was likely due to aggregation of -actin fragments in some of the root cells analyzed. Although occupancy and bundling were not affected by eBL, we found that eccentricity of -actin in LatB- and eBL-treated roots were reduced relative to controls (Figure 5D). It is tempting to speculate that eBL-induced reduction in -actin alignment alone is suf cient to account for  large part of the root autotropic inhibition observed here. It is important to note, however, that all of the -actin analyses reported here were conducted pre-clinorotation. It is possible that changes in -actin organization during the process of clinorotation were unaccounted for in our analyses. Experiments involving chemically  xing roots at various time points during clinorotation or  system in which live roots expressing the - actin reporters can be imaged on  clinostat, will be necessary to address such possibilities. Okamoto et al. (2015) proposed that the long -actin cables in the in orescence stem  ber cells were the structures that modulated organ straightening possibly by regulating cytoplasmic streaming. It is possible that eBL regulation of root autotropic straightening is facilitated by  population of -actin in speci  root cell types that are not detected by the quantitative metrics used in our studies. This could explain why eBL had only modest effects on overall -actin organization, but still caused LatB-like autotropic straightening defects. Another possibility is that dampening of global -actin dynamics by eBL as revealed by live cell imaging of etiolated  truncatula hypocotyls could account for autotropic straightening defects. Suppressed global -actin dynamics after eBL exposure could FIGURE  | Epi-Brassinolide (eBL) inhibited global -actin dynamics in etiolated hypocotyl epidermal cells of . truncatula expressing UBQ10:Lifeact-mGFP. Representative images of three time points (20, 40 and 60 ) of solvent controls () and eBL treated () cells as separate color channels in red, green and blue (RGB) image. White overlay in each image indicates low dynamics. Scale bar = 10 mm. Time-lapse movies corresponding to the merged images are presented as Supplemental Movie S1 (for untreated) and S2 (eBL-treated). Quanti cation of global -actin dynamics based on changes in pixel () and decay of the correlation coef cient (). Statistical analyses of correlation coef cients and total difference in hypocotyl epidermal cells as  function of temporal intervals. Correlation/difference for solvent controls versus eBL-treated hypocotyls are as follows: .02086*/.007597* (20 ); .03*/.006639* (40 ) and .057/.006069* (60 ). Adjusted -values are shown for rejecting equivalence of means; values marked by an asterisk indicate statistical signi cance at the .05 level. de Bang et al. modify targeting of plasma membrane-associated proteins, such as PIN2, leading to dampened autotropism (Li et al., 2005; Lanza et al., 2012). Unfortunately, we were unable to obtain global - actin dynamic data on . truncatula root cells because of technical dif culties associated with keeping actively growing roots within the microscope  eld of view. As such,  direct link between root -actin dynamics and root autotropism is missing. For the future,  suitable clinostat assay using . truncatula shoots should help clarify if reduced global -actin dynamics can explain eBL effects on organ straightening. Furthermore, live  uorescent protein-based -actin marker lines in . mays could help strengthen the link between -actin organization and autotropic organ growth (Wu et al., 2013). For more than  decade, genetically-encoded -actin reporters based on  uorescent protein technology have advanced our understanding of actin function during plant development (Voigt et al., 2005; Wang et al., 2008). In addition to new insights into the processes underlying directional root growth control, our work introduces  set of . truncatula lines expressing two types of genetically encoded -actin reporters. These new -actin reporter lines could potentially be used to address  range of biological questions. Speci cally,  future gravitational biology-related study in which these new . truncatula lines would be of value is the dynamic monitoring of -actin in various tissues of graviresponding roots using vertical stage microscopy (Von Wangenheim et al., 2017). Vertical stage microscopy combined with new imaging modalities such as airy scan should enable super-resolution of -actin during plant gravity response (Komis et al., 2018). Moreover, some light sheet microscopy platforms allow for plant organs to be positioned vertically. Such methods pave the way for long term and volumetric imaging of -actin dynamics during plant gravity response using these new . truncatula lines (Ove ka et al., 2018). Similar to previous reports in . thaliana plants expressing live cell -actin reporters (Ketelaar et al., 2004; Dyachok et al., 2014), mature . truncatula plants expressing Lifeact-mGFP and GFP-ABD2-GFP appear to have growth defects based on their reduced shoot and root dry weights when compared to controls. However, the negative growth effects induced by expressing these reporters were mild and not very pronounced in young seedlings. Thus, if used with caution, these Lifeact-mGFP and GFP-ABD2-GFP . truncatula lines should be  valuable addition to existing  uorescent protein-based toolkit for studying dynamic cellular processes in legumes (Ivanov and Harrison, 2014; Cvrckova and Oulehlova, 2017; Zhang et al., 2019). In conclusion, our results implicate brassinosteroids in root autotropism. Brassinosteroids modulate this process by modifying -actin organization and dynamics in  manner different from that of the actin-disrupting compound LatB. Regardless of the mechanisms by which eBL modi es -actin, our studies reinforce previous observations that the acto-myosin system is an important component of plant tropistic responses. Finally, through our work, we introduced  set of . truncatula lines expressing  uorescent protein-based reporters that could enable new studies of actin-mediated processes in legumes. International Journal of Molecular Sciences Article Cell Type-Speci  Imaging of Calcium Signaling in Arabidopsis thaliana Seedling Roots Using GCaMP3 William Krogman , . Alan Sparks and Elison . Blanca or * Noble Research Institute LLC, 2510 Sam Noble Parkway, Ardmore, OK 73401, USA;  (..);  (...) * Correspondence: eblanca  Received: 22 July 2020; Accepted: 28 August 2020; Published:  September 2020    Abstract: Cytoplasmic calcium ([Ca2+]cyt) is  well-characterized second messenger in eukaryotic cells. An elevation in [Ca2+]cyt levels is one of the earliest responses in plant cells after exposure to  range of environmental stimuli. Advances in understanding the role of [Ca2+]cyt in plant development has been facilitated by the use of genetically-encoded reporters such as GCaMP. Most of these studies have relied on promoters such as Cauli ower Mosaic Virus (35S) and Ubiquitin10 (UBQ10) to drive expression of GCaMP in all cell/tissue types. Plant organs such as roots consist of various cell types that likely exhibit unique [Ca2+]cyt responses to exogenous and endogenous signals. However, few studies have addressed this question. Here, we introduce  set of Arabidopsis thaliana lines expressing GCaMP3 in  ve root cell types including the columella, endodermis, cortex, epidermis, and trichoblasts. We found similarities and di erences in the [Ca2+]cyt signature among these root cell types when exposed to adenosine tri-phosphate (ATP), glutamate, aluminum, and salt, which are known to trigger [Ca2+]cyt increases in root cells. These cell type-targeted GCaMP3 lines provide  new resource that should enable more in depth studies that address how  particular environmental stimulus is linked to speci  root developmental pathways via [Ca2+]cyt. Keywords: GCaMP3; Arabidopsis; cell type speci city; calcium response; [Ca2+]cyt . Introduction Calcium (Ca2+) plays  vital role as  second messenger system in plant development and stress response. Because Ca2+ acts as  stress signal, it is one of the first responses plants have to environmental stimuli. This fast response is achieved through an influx of extracellular Ca2+ and an efflux of stored Ca2+ from the vacuole, endoplasmic reticulum (ER), and mitochondria that is achieved via  concentration gradient between the intracellular Ca2+ stores and the cytoplasm []. In non-stimulated conditions, the concentration of Ca2+ in the cytoplasm rests around 100 nM [ ]. This low concentration is maintained through +/Ca2+ antiporters and Ca2+-ATPases that move Ca2+ into the apoplast or into intracellular stores [,]. Once the response in the cell is initiated, the cell will return to homeostasis by storing excess Ca2+ back in the vacuole, ER, or mitochondria through active transport [], or by pumping it out into extracellular space through gated-ion channels in the plasma membrane. Once Ca2+ enters the cytoplasm in high concentrations, it binds with Ca2+-binding proteins to initiate  second messenger cascade [,]. Part of this signaling cascade is the activation of Ca2+-dependent protein kinases and the regulation of transcription factors to increase tolerance to the stress that caused the initial Ca2+ response. Much of our understanding about Ca2+ as  second messenger has come from the development of technologies that enable monitoring of free cytosolic Ca2+ ([Ca2+]cyt) changes in living cells. Early on, these technologies consisted of indicator dyes that had to be chemically or physically loaded into the cell, such as Calcium Green or Indo-. When Ca2+ levels in the cell became elevated upon exposing the cell to  speci  stimulus, these indicator dyes Int. . Mol. Sci. 2020, 21, 6385; doi:10.3390/ijms21176385 www.mdpi.com/journal/ijms

Int. . Mol. Sci. 2020, 21, 6385  of 15 increased  uorescence []. However, use of these indicator dyes in plant cells were often met with technical challenges including uneven dye loading, loss of cell viability after dye loading, and cells failing to take up the dyes [,]. Problems with these early indicator dyes were mitigated with the discovery of  suite of  uorescent proteins from jelly sh and other marine organisms [,]. Using molecular cloning techniques, selected regions of Ca2+-binding proteins could be fused with these  uorescent proteins to generate genetically-encoded Ca2+ sensors that change conformation upon Ca2+ binding []. Ca2+ binding induced changes in the conformation of  uorescent protein-based sensors result in enhanced  uorescence emission. One example of  genetically-encoded Ca2+ sensor is GCaMP. GCaMP consists of an enhanced green  uorescent protein (eGFP) fused to calmodulin (CaM) and myosin light-chain kinase (M13) [,10]. GCaMP3 is  modi ed form of GCaMP that features  circularly permutated enhanced GFP (eGFP)  anked by CaM and M13 that gives low  uorescence in the absence of Ca2+, which increases upon reversible binding of Ca2+ to the CaM domain [11]. To date, expression of CGaMP and other genetically-encoded Ca2+ sensors in plants are driven by constitutive promoters such as Cauli ower Mosaic Virus 35S (35S) and Ubiquitin 10 (UBQ10) [12,13]. Although plant lines constitutively expressing genetically-encoded Ca2+ sensors enabled the functional study of [Ca2+]cyt changes across entire plant organs [,13,14], it is likely that each cell type within the organ is characterized by  unique [Ca2+]cyt signature. While [Ca2+]cyt changes typically observed in the entire plant organ likely originate from more than one cell type, we lack tools to monitor these changes within speci  tissues or cells [15]. To address this need, we generated  set of lines in the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana, expressing GCaMP3 targeted to the columella, endodermis, epidermis, cortex, and trichoblast using cell-type speci  promoters [16]. We demonstrate the utility of these new GCaMP3 lines in reporting cell-type [Ca2+]cyt changes in roots treated with chemicals previously shown to induce [Ca2+]cyt increases in plants. . Results .. Expression of GCaMP3 in Di erent Root Cell Types of . thaliana To the best of our knowledge, plant lines expressing genetically encoded [Ca2+]cyt sensors that are available to the scienti  community are driven by constitutive promoters. . thaliana lines expressing the UBQ10:GCaMP3 construct, which we generated and used previously to study [Ca2+]cyt oscillations in root hairs [17], is one example. In addition to root hairs, GCaMP3  uorescence was detected in all cell-types of the primary root of . thaliana expressing the UBQ10:GCaMP3 construct (Figure ). Using confocal microscopy, strong  uorescence was observed in cells located at the root surface, such as the peripheral root cap and epidermis (Figure 1A,,). Moderate levels of  uorescence could also be detected in the underlying cortex (Figure 1C). However, in cells located deeper within the root, such as the columella and endodermis,  uorescence was obscured by the  uorescence from surface cells (Figure 1A,). This prompted us to generate  set of constructs that drive GCaMP3 expression in speci  root cell types. For this purpose, we used promoters described in the SWELL promoter collection including ATHB8 (columella), SCARECROW (SCR, endodermis), Pin-Formed  (PIN2, epidermis and cortex), PEP (cortex), and Proline rich protein (PRP3, trichoblasts) [16]. For the  ve constructs, we found that GCaMP3 signal was most prominent in the expected cell types (Figure ). For example, ATHB8 and SCR promoters drove strong GCaMP3 expression in the columella and endodermis, respectively (Figure 2A,). For ATHB8:GCaMP3-expressing lines, we also observed weak  uorescence in the peripheral cap cells and the stele. For SCR:GCaMP3,  uorescence in the endodermis was observed in all root developmental zones from the meristem and elongation zone, continuing into the maturation zone. Roots of PEP:GCaMP3- and PRP3:GCaMP3-expressing seedlings also showed  uorescence in the expected cell types (.., cortex and trichoblast, respectively) (Figure 2C,). On the other hand,

Int. . Mol. Sci. 2020, 21, 6385  of 15  uorescence was detected in the epidermis and cortex of PIN2:GCaMP3-expressing lines, consistent with observations of Marques-Bueno et al. (2016) [16] (Figure 2E). Figure . Confocal imaging of primary roots of -day-old . thaliana seedlings expressing UBQ10:GCaMP3. Representative bright- eld and corresponding single-optical section confocal images of the root tip with  focus on the root cap (), meristem (), and elongation zone (,). = columella; end = endodermis; epi = epidermis; cor = cortex. Scale bar: 50  . Figure . Expression of GCaMP3 in speci  root cell types. Representative bright- eld and confocal images of primary roots of -day-old . thaliana seedlings expressing ATHB8:GCaMP3 (), SCR:GCaMP3 (), and PEP:GCaMP3 (), respectively. ATHB8:GCaMP3 is expressed in the columella with some  uorescence visible in the stele. SCR:GCaMP3 is expressed in the endodermis and PEP:GCaMP3 is expressed in the cortex. Maximum projection images (top panel in ()) and computer reconstructed transverse section (lower panel in ()) of the root maturation zone of seedlings expressing PRP3:GCaMP3 show  uorescence con ned to the trichoblasts. maximum projection image of the root elongation zone of seedlings expressing PIN2:GCaMP3 (). The small box on the upper right corner of panel  shows  computer reconstructed cross-section of the primary root of  PIN2:GCaMP3-expressing line. The image was generated from 50 optical sections taken at .50   intervals. Note that GCaMP3 is predominantly expressed in the epidermis and cortex. = columella; ste = stele; epi = epidermis; cor = cortex; end = endodermis;  = trichoblast;  = atrichoblasts. Scale bar: 50  . .. Chemical Treatments of Cell-Type Speci  GCaMP3 Constructs Studies on Ca2+ signaling in plants over several years have revealed various stimuli that can trigger  rapid elevation in [Ca2+]cyt including cold, touch, wounding, hormones, reactive oxygen

Int. . Mol. Sci. 2020, 21, 6385  of 15 species, cyclic nucleotides, amino acids and nutrient/ionic stress [,18 23]. We used some of these known [Ca2+]cyt triggers to test the responsiveness of our root cell-speci  GCaMP3 lines. We  rst analyzed the response of the GCaMP3 lines to adenosine tri-phosphate (ATP) (Figure ). In mammalian systems, ATP is  neurotransmitter that is perceived by plasma membrane bound purinergic receptors, and its signaling role is facilitated through increases in [Ca2+]cyt [24]. While plants do not have the canonical purinergic receptors found in mammals, they perceive ATP via lectin receptor-like kinases and, similar to mammals, ATP elicits  rapid increase in [Ca2+]cyt [25 27]. Comparable to previous reports, application of ATP to the elongation zone of roots expressing UBQ10:GCaMP3 elicited  rapid rise in [Ca2+]cyt-dependent  uorescence followed by  gradual decline (Figure 3A) [,25]. To determine if the increase in [Ca2+]cyt was due exclusively to ATP, we applied the solvent control solution, which consisted of . Murashige Skoog (MS) solution without ATP to roots. We found that applying MS solution triggered  rise in [Ca2+]cyt that was delayed and lower in amplitude compared to the [Ca2+]cyt change caused by ATP (Figure 3A). This observation suggests that under our growing conditions, adding  drop of solvent control solution to the root can induce an increase in [Ca2+]cyt, which could be the result of  touch or hypoosmotic response [19,20,27,28]. Therefore, in testing the cell-type GCaMP3 lines, we included solvent control applications in all of the experiments so we could tease apart [Ca2+]cyt changes due to the desired stimulus from those resulting from  touch or hypoosmotic response. Figure . Time course of [Ca2+]cyt changes in . thaliana roots after  mM ATP application. The leftmost panel shows an inverted  uorescence image of the terminal 300   of an . thaliana primary root to illustrate di erent cells in which GCaMP3 was expressed. Cell types are color coded with green = epidermis; blue = cortex; orange = endodermis; purple = columella; and the pink cells in the inset in panel  = trichoblast. ( ) Quanti cation of [Ca2+]cyt -dependent  uorescence of various lines expressing GCaMP3 after ATP and solvent control (. MS) application. Black arrows indicate the time of treatment. Plotted values represent the average normalized  uorescence intensity from   regions of interest (ROI) per line with standard error bars every  fth time point. Fluorescence values were normalized to the lowest  uorescence value. Upon applying ATP to roots expressing cell-speci  GCaMP3 lines, we found similarities and di erences in the resulting [Ca2+]cyt signatures. For example, the PIN2:GCaMP3 lines, which expressed GCaMP3 in the epidermis and cortex (Figure ), displayed similar [Ca2+]cyt signatures as UBQ10:GCaMP3-expressing lines in response to ATP and the solvent control solution (Figure 3A,). This is not surprising given that GCaMP3 is strongly expressed in both the epidermis and cortex under the control of the UBQ10 and PIN2 promoters (Figures  and ). For lines expressing GCaMP3 in the trichoblasts, application of both ATP and MS control solution triggered  small increase in [Ca2+]cyt that had similar patterns (Figure 3C).

The next chemical we used to test the cell-speci  GCaMP3 lines was glutamic acid (Figure ). Like ATP, glutamic acid (glutamate) is  neurotransmitter in mammalian cells that can trigger  [Ca2+]cyt increase [,14]. Application of glutamate to the elongation zone of roots expressing the UBQ10:GCaMP3 construct induced  strong initial [Ca2+]cyt increase with  quick return to equilibrium (Figure 4A). The [Ca2+]cyt spikes induced by application of MS controls were also observed in this dataset. Compared to glutamate, the onset of [Ca2+]cyt increase was delayed in roots treated with MS solution. In this case, however, the [Ca2+]cyt spikes triggered by glutamate and the MS control solution were similar in amplitude (Figure 4A). Like the ATP treatment, [Ca2+]cyt response of roots expressing PIN2:GCaMP3 to glutamate was similar to roots expressing UBQ10:GCaMP3. Furthermore, [Ca2+]cyt changes in the root elongation zone of PIN2:GCaMP3-expressing seedlings in response to the MS control solution was delayed, but exhibited  lower amplitude (Figure 4B). Lines expressing PRP3:GCaMP3 also had  strong initial [Ca2+]cyt peak after glutamate treatment with  rapid return to equilibrium that resembled UBQ10:GCaMP3 and PIN2:GCaMP3 lines. Like UBQ10:GCaMP3 and PIN2:GCaMP3 lines, application of MS control solution elicited  [Ca2+]cyt response that was delayed when compared to glutamate exposure (Figure 4C). By contrast, PEP:GCaMP3-expressing lines showed  dampened response to glutamate compared to lines in which GCaMP3 was expressed in the root surface (Figure 4D). Close examination of the time course of [Ca2+]cyt signals in the cortex after glutamate application revealed  triphasic response, with two larger peaks and  delayed smaller peak. Surprisingly, the amplitude of glutamate-triggered [Ca2+]cyt increases in the cortex was less than that of MS treated roots (Figure 4D). The lines expressing SCR:GCaMP3 and ATHB8:GCaMP3 showed monophasic responses to glutamate with  gradual return to equilibrium, similar to lines in which GCaMP3 was expressed in root surface cells. Furthermore, unlike lines with GCaMP expressed in the cortex and root surface cells, the MS control solution response for endodermis- and columella- targeted GCaMP3 had delayed responses and lower amplitudes (Figure 4E,). Similar to previous treatments, the root elongation zone of seedlings expressing UBQ10:GCaMP3 showed  monophasic [Ca2+]cyt response to Al3+ (Figure 5A). Our analysis showed that reaction time was delayed in lines where GCaMP3 was expressed in inner cell types. When comparing the di erent chemical treatments, ATP, glutamate, and Al3+ showed similar responses (except ATHB8:GCaMP3 to Al3+) while adapted ATP:MS showed signi cantly slower reaction times to both ATP and glutamate (Table ). Evaluation of [Ca2+]cyt Signatures from Similar Root Development Regions and Cell Types In comparing UBQ10:GCaMP3 lines with the other cell-type speci  GCaMP3 lines,  ROI was selected and the average of normalized  uorescence intensity was plotted. For the most part, the ROI in UBQ10:GCaMP3 lines was from the root epidermis and the average normalized  uorescence intensity from this ROI was compared with that of individual or groups of cells from the cell-type speci  GCaMP3 lines. This process did not enable direct comparisons of [Ca2+]cyt signatures between the same cell types or root developmental regions. To address this issue, we conducted another set of imaging experiments using ATP-treated UBQ10:GCaMP3 and PIN2:GCaMP3 lines. For these experiments,  more direct comparison was conducted by drawing ROIs in epidermal cells from similar positions along the root longitudinal axis encompassing the meristem, distal elongation zone, and central elongation zone (Figure 8A). In doing so, we found similarities and di erences in [Ca2+]cyt signatures between UBQ10:GCaMP3 and PIN2:GCaMP3 lines. For example, the ATP-induced [Ca2+]cyt signatures of UBQ10:GCaMP3 in all root developmental regions were identical to those in the distal and central elongation zone of PIN2:GCaMP3 lines. In PIN2:GCaMP3 lines, however, the ATP-induced [Ca2+]cyt signature had  much greater amplitude in the meristem (Figure 8A,). We extended our analysis by drawing ROIs in presumptive columella or endodermis of UBQ10:GCaMP3 and comparing the resulting [Ca2+]cyt signatures from these ROIs with those of ATHB8:GCaMP3 and SCR:GCaMP3. For the columella, we found that ATHB8:GCaMP3 lines displayed an ATP-triggered [Ca2+]cyt signature with  sustained peak throughout the 10 min time course. On the other hand, the ATP-induced [Ca2+]cyt signature from the presumptive columella region of UBQ10:GCaMP3 lines was transient (Figure 8C). For the endodermis, the peak of ATP-induced [Ca2+]cyt increase was higher in UBQ10:GCaMP3 when compared to SCR:GCaMP3 (Figure 8D). Int. . Mol. Sci. 2020, 21, 6385 10 of 15 Figure . Discussion In this paper, we introduced  set of . thaliana lines expressing the intensiometric [Ca2+]cyt reporter GCaMP3 targeted to speci  root cell types. Roots of these cell type speci  GCaMP3 lines responded to chemical treatments such as ATP, glutamate, Al3+, and NaCl by exhibiting increases in [Ca2+]cyt-dependent CGaMP3  uorescence. Imaging [Ca2+]cyt changes in cell types in response to some of these chemicals using lines in which genetically-encoded [Ca2+]cyt reporters are expressed ubiquitously have been attempted previously. This was done by drawing  region of interest corresponding to  particular tissue/cell type. For example, it was shown that Al3+-induced biphasic [Ca2+]cyt signatures in the root elongation zone occurred predominantly in the cortex when compared with the epidermis []. While this has proven  ective for marking developmental regions along the longitudinal axis of the root [,27], specifying  region of interest to designate root tissue/cell types along the radial axis for  uorescence-based measurements of [Ca2+]cyt can be problematic because this does not guarantee complete separation of signals from adjacent cell types. This problem becomes even more challenging for cell types located in the innermost regions of the root such as the columella and endodermis. Moreover, the ability to consistently draw  region of interest to outline the root cortex requires that the root grew in  particular orientation during the imaging experiments []. Here, we documented some of the advantages of the cell type speci  GCaMP3 lines by comparing [Ca2+]cyt signatures from ROIs marking presumptive columella and endodermis in UBQ10:GCaMP3

Int. . Mol. Sci. 2020, 21, 6385 11 of 15 lines with those of ATHB8:GCaMP3 and SCR:GCaMP3. This analysis revealed stark di erences in both the amplitude and shape of [Ca2+]cyt signatures. Di erences were also uncovered when equivalent root developmental regions were compared, particularly with regard to the amplitude of [Ca2+]cyt signatures in the meristem (Figure ). The di erences are likely due to contaminating signals from other cell types in UBQ10:GCaMP3 lines. The use of cell type speci  GCaMP3 lines described here could potentially mitigate such problems. The [Ca2+]cyt transients in the cell type speci  lines induced by these various chemicals had various patterns when compared with lines in which GCaMP3 was expressed ubiquitously. similarity in patterns occurred within the root surface cells  responses to the di erent chemical treatments and again within the root inner cell types. Lines in which GCaMP3 was expressed in innermost root cell types such as the columella and endodermis generally had slower response times when compared to lines with GCaMP3 expressed in root surface cells. The delayed response times in lines with GCaMP3 expressed in the columella and endodermis was observed in all chemical treatments (Table ; Figure ). One could argue that because of the innermost location of the columella and endodermis, the delay in the response times might be due to the longer time it takes for the chemical to make contact with the target cells. The fact that columella and endodermis exhibit minimal or no [Ca2+]cyt increase after application of .5X MS supports this possibility. An alternative hypothesis is that the delayed [Ca2+]cyt response in the innermost cell types is due to an inward moving [Ca2+]cyt wave, which is not easily revealed when GCaMP3 is expressed ubiquitously or on the root surface. From our data, these inward-directed [Ca2+]cyt waves appear to be most prominent in ATP- and glutamate-treated roots (Figures ,  and ). The GCaMP3 lines described here could present  signi cant tool for better understanding the radial direction of [Ca2+]cyt waves in roots. meaningful set of experiments with GCaMP3 lines expressed in innermost cell types will be to locally apply  small volume of the chemical stimulus to the root epidermis. The line that was most similar to UBQ10:GCaMP3 with regard to chemical-induced [Ca2+]cyt transients was PIN2:GCaMP3. This was not surprising given that the PIN2 promoter drives GCaMP3 expression in root epidermal cells, which is the cell type that is readily imaged in UBQ10:GCaMP3 lines due to its location on the root surface. With the PEP:GCaMP3 lines described here, we were able observe biphasic, triphasic and oscillatory [Ca2+]cyt signatures after Al3+ treatment that were reminiscent of some of the observations made by Rincon-Zachary et al. (2010) [] (Figure ). The cortex- and trichoblast-targeted GCaMP3 lines also revealed an earlier onset of NaCl-induced [Ca2+]cyt transients when compared to UBQ10:GCaMP3 lines (Figure ). It has been shown that [Ca2+]cyt transients in roots exposed to NaCl is part of the cellular machinery that prevents root cells from rupturing under salinity stress. The plasma membrane-localized receptor-like kinase, Feronia (FER), is required for root growth recovery after encountering high salinity conditions [31]. Because fer mutants displayed  high incidence of cortical cell rupture when compared to wild type after exposure to NaCl, it is tempting to speculate that earlier onset of [Ca2+]cyt transients in the cortex revealed by the PEP:GCaMP3-expressing lines could be  mechanism to maintain root growth integrity. The cell type GCaMP3 lines described here should be useful in testing this hypothesis. While testing the various cell type speci  GCaMP3 lines, we encountered  number of technical challenges brought about by our seedling growth conditions. In several experiments, we found that applying the .5X MS control solution alone could trigger  rise in [Ca2+]cyt. The MS only-induced [Ca2+]cyt transients were most prominent in the UBQ10:GCaMP3-expressing lines and those in which GCaMP3 was expressed in root surface cell types (.., PIN2:GCaMP3 and PRP3:GCaMP3). The [Ca2+]cyt transients observed after MS treatment were reminiscent of touch-induced [Ca2+]cyt responses [20], and recent studies on ATP-induced [Ca2+]cyt signaling [27], suggesting that we might have been eliciting  touch response as the various solutions were added to the root.

text:
The plasma membrane-localized receptor-like kinase, Feronia (FER), is required for root growth recovery after encountering high salinity conditions [31]. Because fer mutants displayed  high incidence of cortical cell rupture when compared to wild type after exposure to NaCl, it is tempting to speculate that earlier onset of [Ca2+]cyt transients in the cortex revealed by the PEP:GCaMP3-expressing lines could be  mechanism to maintain root growth integrity. The cell type GCaMP3 lines described here should be useful in testing this hypothesis. While testing the various cell type speci  GCaMP3 lines, we encountered  number of technical challenges brought about by our seedling growth conditions. In several experiments, we found that applying the .5X MS control solution alone could trigger  rise in [Ca2+]cyt. The MS only-induced [Ca2+]cyt transients were most prominent in the UBQ10:GCaMP3-expressing lines and those in which GCaMP3 was expressed in root surface cell types (.., PIN2:GCaMP3 and PRP3:GCaMP3). The [Ca2+]cyt transients observed after MS treatment were reminiscent of touch-induced [Ca2+]cyt responses [20], and recent studies on ATP-induced [Ca2+]cyt signaling [27], suggesting that we might have been eliciting  touch response as the various solutions were added to the root. In support of this hypothesis, our method for root [Ca2+]cyt imaging involved planting seed of the reporter lines on  thin layer of agarose to secure the root while at the same time allowing for the root cells to be accessible to the various chemical treatments ([]; see Methods). It is possible that some of the [Ca2+]cyt transients

Int. . Mol. Sci. 2020, 21, 6385 12 of 15 observed in response to MS application resulted from roots that were not securely anchored to the agarose medium. Alternatively, the prevalence of MS-induced [Ca2+]cyt increases in some of our experiments could be due to osmotic changes when the solution was applied. Because agar for imaging roots was poured in advance, it was possible that liquid in some of the plates may have evaporated during storage. This could have led to some plates having an MS solution that was more concentrated than the treatment solution. To test the possibility that MS-induced [Ca2+]cyt changes were due to touch or hypoosmotic shock, we repeated the ATP application experiments using roots that emerged from seeds planted on plates with freshly prepared MS-supplemented agarose. Furthermore, roots were pretreated with MS solution prior to ATP treatment. Under these modi ed growth and treatment conditions, we found that MS-induced [Ca2+]cyt increases were signi cantly dampened (Figures  and ). Given that [Ca2+]cyt changes are responses that can be elicited by  wide range of stimuli, the results described here highlight the need to carefully consider the growth and treatment conditions, and to include appropriate controls when conducting [Ca2+]cyt imaging experiments. Based on these observations, it is imperative that fresh plates be prepared prior to planting the reporter lines and that roots be pretreated with the solvent control solution for  few hours to allow seedlings to adapt. Some studies have shown [Ca2+]cyt signals propagate along the longitudinal axis of roots [,26]. Meanwhile, another study has indicated that [Ca2+]cyt signal propagation from the apical into the sub-apical can also occur [27]. The cell type speci  GCaMP3 lines described here, particularly those lines in which GCaMP3 is expressed in inner root cells such as the cortex-, endodermis- and columella-speci  lines could shed new insights into the direction of [Ca2+]cyt signal propagation within the roots. The MS-induced [Ca2+]cyt responses in lines in which GCaMP3 was expressed in the endodermis and columella were not observed. However, these cell types exhibited [Ca2+]cyt increases in response to some of the chemicals, indicating that these [Ca2+]cyt changes can be attributed to the chemical itself. In this regard, it is noteworthy that columella-targeted GCaMP3 lines did not exhibit  [Ca2+]cyt increase after Al3+ treatment while those lines with GCaMP3 expressed in the endodermis lacked  [Ca2+]cyt response to NaCl. With the establishment of response patterns from the cell type speci  GCaMP3 lines when exposed to various chemical treatments, investigation into unique aspects of di erent root tissues/cells, such as signal propagation direction and response intensity, can be more readily explored. . Chimeras reveal  single lipid-interface residue that controls MscL channel kinetics as well as mechanosensitivity Li-Min Yang1,, Dalian Zhong1,, and Paul Blount1,* 1Department of Physiology, UT Southwestern Medical center at Dallas, 5323 Harry Hines Blvd, Dallas TX 75390-9040 Summary MscL, the highly conserved bacterial mechanosensitive channel of large conductance, functionally serves as an osmotic  emergency release valve , is among the best studied mechanosensors and  paradigm of how  channel senses and responds to membrane tension. While all homologues tested thus far encode channel activity, many show functional differences. Here we tested . coli and  aureus chimeras and find that the periplasmic region of the protein, particularly . coli I49 and the equivalent  aureus F47 at the periplasmic lipid-aqueous interface of the first transmembrane domain, drastically influences both the open dwell time and threshold of channel opening. One mutant shows  severe hysteresis, confirming the importance of this residue in determining the energy barriers for channel gating. We propose that this site acts similar to  spring for  clasp knife, adjusting the resistance for obtaining and stabilizing an open or closed channel structure. Keywords mechanosensitive channel; channel kinetics; osmoregulation; protein-lipid interactions Introduction The ability to detect mechanical forces is at the basis of not only the senses of touch, hearing and balance but also cardiovascular and osmotic regulation. In essence, mechanosensation is probably the oldest sense and is fundamental for many life functions. The primary way that organisms detect forces is through mechanosensitive (MS) ion channels. The best-studied mechanosensitive channels are from bacteria, and because relatively little is known of mechanosensors from higher organisms, these channels are  model for how  protein can sense and respond to mechanical forces. 2013 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved. *Correspondence should be addressed to PB 214-645-6014 (). 2These authors contributed equally to this work Author Contributions LY and DZ contributed equally. DZ made the vast majority of the chimera constructs. LY produced, analyzed, and interpreted the majority of the patch clamp traces; LY also served as  mentor and teacher for DZ mastering electrophysiology, and both ultimately contributed to this aspect of the project. PB conceived of and supervised the project. All authors contributed to the writing of the paper. Publisher' Disclaimer: This is  PDF file of an unedited manuscript that has been accepted for publication. As  service to our customers we are providing this early version of the manuscript. The manuscript will undergo copyediting, typesetting, and review of the resulting proof before it is published in its final citable form. Please note that during the production process errors may be discovered which could affect the content, and all legal disclaimers that apply to the journal pertain. NIH Public Access Author Manuscript Cell Rep. Author manuscript; available in PMC 2013 March 11. Published in final edited form as: Cell Rep. 2013 February 21; (): 520 527. doi:10.1016/.celrep.2013.01.018. NIH-PA Author Manuscript NIH-PA Author Manuscript NIH-PA Author Manuscript

The mechanosensitive channel of large conductance (MscL) is  bacterial channel located in the cytoplasmic membrane that is gated by membrane tension (Blount et al., 2008a; Blount et al., 2007; Blount et al., 2008b; Booth and Blount, 2012). Although observed in the vast majority of bacterial species, the channels from Escherichia coli (. coli) have been the best studied. The physiological role of MscL, and members of an unrelated bacterial mechanosensitive channel family, MscS ( for small conductance), is to serve as biological  emergency release valves  to protect cells from lysis upon an acute decrease in osmotic environment, commonly referred to as osmotic downshock; it accomplishes this by rapidly releasing cytoplasmic osmolytes (Booth and Blount, 2012; Levina et al., 1999). The MscL channel is less sensitive than MscS to membrane tension, but it generates  larger pore size, upwards of 30  (Cruickshank et al., 1997), suggesting it is the last-ditch effort for survival. The MscL family is highly conserved and has  simple structural organization (Balleza and Gomez-Lagunas, 2009; Pivetti et al., 2003). This exaggerated response and simple construction lends itself as  paradigm for how MS channels, in general, can sense and respond to membrane stretch. -ray crystallography has resolved  MscL homologue from Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Tb-MscL) to be  homopentamer with each subunit containing an amphipathic -terminal cytoplasmic  -helix running along the cytoplasmic membrane, followed by the two transmembrane  -helices (TM1 and TM2) that are connected by  periplasmic loop, and ending with the five -terminal  -helixes forming  cytoplasmic helical bundle (Chang et al., 1998; Steinbacher et al., 2007) (also see Fig. 1A). more recent structure has also been resolved for the Staphylococcus aureus (. aureus) MscL orthologue (Sa-MscL), which shows  tetrameric rather than pentameric complex (Liu et al., 2009); however, this appears to be  detergent-induced oligomeric rearrangement since the channel forms almost exclusively pentamers in vivo (Dorwart et al., 2010; Iscla et al., 2011). Although the Sa- MscL structure is unlikely to be physiologically relevant, it is worth noting that many of the interactions between the transmembrane domains are similar to those observed in the Tb- MscL crystal structure, suggesting an overall structural conservation within this highly conserved family. Although highly homologous, MscL channels from different species can vary in threshold of activation, conductance and open dwell time (Folgering et al., 2005; Maurer et al., 2000; Moe et al., 1998). For example, Sa-MscL has  sequence identity of 47% and similarity of 69% with . coli MscL (Eco-MscL) (Fig. 1B); however, the major physiological differences between the activities of these channels is that the Sa-MscL has much shorter open dwell times (Moe et al., 1998) and requires greater membrane tension to open. To identify the structural features underlying these functional differences, we have generated chimeras in which we have exchanged protein domains, subdomains, and ultimately even individual amino acids, and determined the kinetics and threshold of activation of the resulting channels. Surprisingly, the data indicate that the periplasmic region of the protein, particularly one residue located at the TM1/periplasmic loop lipid interface, plays  major role in both the open dwell time and threshold of activation, or, for simplicity, what we will from here on refer to as mechanosensitivity of the channel. The finding that  site at the membrane interface plays such  crucial physiological role affirms the intimate interactions that membrane-tension-gated channels have with their lipid environment. Results The periplasmic region of the channel plays  major role in defining channel kinetics In an attempt to correlate channel kinetics with specific regions of the protein, numerous chimeras of the Eco- and Sa-MscL channel proteins were generated. Figure  shows the locations of different domains of the protein imposed upon the crystal structure of the Tb- Yang et al. Page  Cell Rep. Author manuscript; available in PMC 2013 March 11. NIH-PA Author Manuscript NIH-PA Author Manuscript NIH-PA Author Manuscript

MscL (panel ) as well as the sequence alignment of the Eco- and Sa-MscL proteins (panel ). The nomenclature of all chimeras tested is as follows:  and  represent regions from Eco- and Sa-MscL protein, respectively, which is followed by numbers showing the locations according to the Eco-MscL registry. As shown in Figure , recording the single channel openings of many Eco- and Sa-MscL chimeras revealed  pattern in channel open dwell time. Figure 2A shows chimeras with very short open dwell times, similar to wild type Sa-MscL. Chimeras in this panel share  common sequence in what is essentially the TM1/ periplasmic loop lipid interface of the Sa-MscL, specifically amino acids (aa) 44-49. In contrast to chimeras shown in Figure 2A, channels shown in Figure 2B share  common sequence in the same region which, instead is from Eco-MscL. These chimeras also contain the periplasmic loop and beginning of TM2 from Eco-MscL, thus giving  total Eco-MscL domain of aa 44-77. This common sequence correlates with longer open dwell times, similar to the Eco-MscL activities. The analyses of additional chimeras demonstrated that different subdomains of this entire periplasmic region, aa 44-77, effect different behaviors in channel kinetics. The most dramatic example is seen in Figure 2C, where we found that if  channel contains the TM1 periplasmic region of Eco-MscL, aa 44-49, as well as the periplasmic loop region from Sa- MscL, aa 50-77,  super-long open dwell time channel is produced, thus suggesting that both regions lead to stabilization of the open state; note that the time scale of the two chimeras in this panel is 86-fold and 140-fold of that for chimeras shown in panels  and , respectively. This latter observation allows us to make some predictions. It first suggests that  combination of Sa-MscL  shortening  effects of Sa-MscL 44-49 and Eco-MscL aa 50-77 should yield  channel with  super-short  channel kinetics. While Figure 2A is consistent with this prediction, it cannot be rigorously tested; the equipment used cannot easily resolve channel openings below 1ms, which is approximately the longest opening for the Sa-MscL channel. However, it also predicts that  combination of the  shortening  effects of Sa-MscL aa 44-49 with the  lengthening  effects of Sa-MscL aa 50-77 in an Eco-MscL background would lead to  channel with intermediate kinetics, perhaps not dissimilar to Eco-MscL. Indeed, as seen in Figure 2D, this prediction is upheld. Since aa 50-77 contains both the non- conserved periplasmic loop (aa 50-74) as well as the highly conserved beginning of TM2 (aa 75-77), the different effect of aa 50-77 from Sa- and Eco-MscL is very likely generated by differences in the periplasmic loop (aa 50-74). The effects of the periplasmic loop are not easily attributed to  shorter sub-domain. Chimeras containing the end of TM1 (aa 44-49) from Eco-MscL and only the latter part of periplasmic loop region (aa 56-77) from Sa-MscL also show an increase in open dwell times, but not as dramatic as that observed in Figure 2C (in Fig. S1). Hence, the nonconserved periplasmic loop appears to act as  unit in its regulation of channel kinetics. While the region of the protein from aa 44-77 appears to play  vital role in defining the kinetics of the channel, any structure/function relationship of conductance and mechanosensitivity appears to be much more complicated. There is no obvious correlation between these periplasmic regions and channel conductance or mechanosensitivity. For example, using an accepted mechanosensitivity gage(Blount et al., 1999; Blount et al., 1996a; Ou et al., 1998) where MscS is used as an internal standard within the patch, and the ratio of gating threshold pressure for MscL (pL) divided by the threshold pressure of MscS (pS) is determined, we found the pL/pS ratio ranged from .85 to . with wild type Eco- MscL at .47 and Sa-MscL at .96, and the most sensitive chimera, SES56-77 (ratio .85), and one of the least sensitive, ESE44-77 (ratio .), are in the same group shown in Figure 2A. For these chimeras we could find no correlation between either conductance or mechanosensitivity with the channel open dwell times. Yang et al. Page  Cell Rep. In summary, as shown in Figure 2C, the aa 44-49 region from Eco-MscL and the periplasmic loop from Sa-MscL confer long open dwell times, while aa 44-49 from Sa- MscL and periplasmic loop from Eco-MscL confer short open dwell times. Hence, the combination of Eco-MscL aa 44-49 and Sa-MscL periplasmic loop leads to MscL channels with extremely long openings, as shown in Figure 2C. single residue at the TM1/periplasmic loop lipid interface has  pronounced effect on channel kinetics In contrast to the periplasmic loop, the periplasmic portion of TM1 is small and relatively conserved. Note that the SES44-49 chimera shown in Figure 2C, which has extremely long open dwell times, contains only  alternative residues relative to the wild type Sa-MscL channel (G46 is conserved). In order to determine if  specific site within the end of TM1 (aa 44-49) is responsible for controlling open dwell times, we generated site-directed mutations. As shown in Figure 3A, mutations of the Eco-MscL residues within this region were systematically changed back to the Sa-MscL sequence. Note that the SES44-49 chimera shown in Figure 2C, which has extremely long open dwell times, contains only  alternative residues relative to the wild type Sa-MscL channel (G46 is conserved). In order to determine if  specific site within the end of TM1 (aa 44-49) is responsible for controlling open dwell times, we generated site-directed mutations. As shown in Figure 3A, mutations of the Eco-MscL residues within this region were systematically changed back to the Sa-MscL sequence. Changing P44 back to , PL44-45 to LI, L47 to  and L48 to  had no apparent effect on the aberrantly long channel openings. In contrast, mutation of I49 to  drastically reduced the channel open dwell time. small, and as of yet unexplained change in conductance was noted: I49F was .48 .04 nS, while the other mutants ranged from .80 to .05 nS; however, all were much larger than the conductance of Sa-MscL (. . nS), again suggesting that this is not  site of major regulation of channel conductance. On the other hand, the data indicate that residue 49, located at the TM1/periplasmic loop lipid interface, is an important site for defining channel kinetics. If residue 49 indeed controls the open dwell time, then mutation of this residue within wild type Sa- and Eco-MscL backgrounds should also alter channel kinetics. We therefore exchanged the amino acids at this location. As shown in Figure 3B, mutation of Eco-MscL I49 to the residue of the comparable site of Sa-MscL, , generates  channel with short open dwell times, similar to the Sa-MscL. Conversely, mutation of the Sa-MscL equivalent site, F47, to the Eco-MscL  leads to  channel with pronounced long open dwell times. Consistent with our findings that the Sa-MscL periplasmic loop defines long open dwell times, isoleucine at this site in the wild type Sa-MscL background leads to much longer channel openings than observed for the wild type Eco-MscL activity. Therefore, the Eco- MscL I49, and the Sa-MscL equivalent site, F47, is important in controlling the open dwell time of wild type MscL channels as well as chimeras. In sum, these data demonstrate that  single amino acid at the periplasmic end of TM1 can have dramatic effects on the stabilization of the open state of the channel. Additional mutational analysis of the single residue at the TM1/periplasmic loop lipid interface shows  correlation of the properties of residue substitutions with channel kinetics and mechanosensitivity In an attempt to determine the possible mechanisms for the role of this site in controlling channel openings, we mutated F47 in Sa- MscL into different amino acids. As shown in Figure 4A, Figure S2 and Table S1, mutations at this site led to channels with varying open dwell times that correlate with the hydrophobicity of the substitutions (r2=.34, =.047). The hydrophobic amino acids  and  effected very long openings while those with charged side chains,  and , led to shorter openings. However, all three aromatic amino acids anomalously led to very short openings. Among all the mutants that effect long open dwell times, F47L had an obvious hysteresis. As shown in Figure 4B, the channel showed  delay of several seconds in both opening and closing upon pressure changes. Boltzmann functions of open probability (Po) versus Yang et al. Page  Cell Rep. Author manuscript; available in PMC 2013 March 11. NIH-PA Author Manuscript NIH-PA Author Manuscript NIH-PA Author Manuscript

pressure were quite different for opening (P1/ = . of pL/pS) and closing (P1/ = . of pL/ pS) when the duration of each pressure step is from . to 4s. The difference of the P1/ for channel opening and closing was not apparent when slower pressure ramp (> 30s) was applied. Such hysteresis was also noted for the chimeras, SES44-49 and ESE50-77, discussed above, and appears to be an extreme exaggeration of  very mild hysteresis (less than  10% change between opening and closing P1/) of the wild type Eco-MscL reported previously (Kamaraju et al., 2010). All of the mutations at Sa-F47 caused  decrease in pL/pS ratio reflecting  more sensitive channel, as shown in Figure 4C and Figure S2. Moreover, the pL/pS ratio correlated with the hydrophobicity of the amino acid substitutions (r2=., =.027), with hydrophobic amino acids effecting higher pL/pS ratios, and thus reflecting  channel that is less sensitive to membrane tension. In contrast with the kinetic data discussed above, and as shown in Figure 4A, the three  bulky  aromatic amino acids followed this correlation with mechanosensitivity well (Fig. 4C), suggesting  different mechanism underlying how the hydrophobicity of residue 47 affects channel kinetics and mechanosensitivity; in essence, the outliers for the correlation shown in Figure 4A are not seen in 4C. Consistent with this hypothesis, no correlation between open dwell time and pL/pS ratio of all mutations at F47 was observed (Fig. 4D). In summary, the above data confirm that the residue at this location plays  profound role in defining Sa-MscL open dwell times as well as mechanosensation; while hydrophobicity and  bulk  may help to define the channel kinetics, hydrophobicity alone plays the major role in determining mechanosensitivity. To test whether the equivalent site, I49, in Eco-MscL also plays an important role in channel function, we selectively mutated I49 to , , and . Surprisingly, we found that same mutations changed channel kinetics and mechanosensitivity with  similar trend as that observed for Sa-MscL (Fig. 5A and  and Fig. S3). These data suggest that this site has  conserved function among orthologues. Discussion While several studies on Eco- or Tb-MscL have suggested that the periplasmic region may play  role in MscL channel regulation (Ajouz et al., 2000; Blount et al., 1996b; Jeon and Voth, 2008; Maurer et al., 2000; Maurer and Dougherty, 2003; Park et al., 2004; Tsai et al., 2005), no one had successfully identified  single sub-domain or residue that acted as  variable spring element, in either  consistent or opposing manner, across bacterial species. In this study, using  chimera approach we were able to identify such subdomains, and ultimately,  single residue. We initially found that the periplasmic loop of Eco-MscL confers short channel openings and that of Sa-MscL defines long openings. In contrast, the relatively conserved TM1/ periplasmic lipid interface (44 49) influenced channel kinetics in an opposite manner with that from Eco-MscL effecting long open dwell times, and that from Sa-MscL generating short open dwell times. Thus, these two periplasmic regions appear to work in concert within these two orthologues, and the engineered combination of the Eco-MscL TM1/ periplasmic lipid interface and the Sa-MscL periplasmic loop leads to MscL channels with  stabilized open state and extremely long open dwell times. The further dissection of the TM1/periplasmic loop interface led to the finding that  single residue at the lipid interface, I49 for Eco-MscL and the analogous site F47 for Sa-MscL, has profound effects on channel kinetics, thus suggesting an important role of protein-lipid interactions at this region. Furthermore, we generated one particular mutant by site directed mutagenesis, Sa-MscL F47L, which has an extreme channel phenotype in that it shows  Yang et al. Page  Cell Rep. Author manuscript; available in PMC 2013 March 11. NIH-PA Author Manuscript NIH-PA Author Manuscript NIH-PA Author Manuscript

severe hysteresis as well as delay in both opening and closing. These data demonstrate that not only can the energy barrier for gating, or the transition between closed and open states, be modified by  mutation at Sa-F47, but that the transition from closed to open can be drastically different from that for going from open to closed states. recent molecular dynamic simulation study on Eco-MscL channel gating suggests that, during the gating process, membrane thinning induces  kink within the TM1/periplasmic loop interface, essentially in and around Eco-I49, which causes outward motion of the periplasmic loop away from the pore center (Deplazes et al., 2012). We propose that the easing or resisting of some restraint, such as this proposed kink formation, may modulate the transition between open and closed states, like adjusting the spring on  clasp knife. Studying additional channels altered by site-directed mutagenesis, we found consistent correlations between residue properties and their effects on channel function for Sa- as well as Eco-MscL; these data suggest  common functional role for this site between orthologues. As  general rule, hydrophobic residues led to longer open times, although streamlined hydrophobic residues appear to be more efficient in this aspect than those containing bulkier aromatic rings, presumably because of some sort of steric hindrance of the latter. The role of this residue in channel mechanosensation was also studied, and more hydrophobic substitutions were found to decrease mechanosensitivity. Therefore, increasing the hydrophobicity appears to increase the energy barrier required to achieve an open state, but once achieved, the open state is stabilized; increasing the hydrophilicity does the opposite, demonstrating that this spring element is adjusted by hydrophobicity. These findings are reminiscent of early studies suggesting that hydrophobic interactions, coined   hydrophobic lock , at the pore constriction keeps the channel closed; according to this theory, it is the exposure of these residues to the aqueous solution that is  major energy barrier for channel opening (Blount et al., 2007; Blount and Moe, 1999; Moe et al., 2000; Yoshimura et al., 1999). Note, however, that the  lock  is due to the bundling of hydrophobic residues from each of the subunits at the constriction of the pore, whereas here we found  residue at the lipid interface where no such bundling of residues is likely to occur. Although we found that the hydrophobicity of this spring element at the TM1 periplasmic lipid interface is important in both channel kinetics and mechanosensation, it is important to note that there are differences in the two correlations. For example, aromatic amino acids fit the hydropathy correlation for mechanosensation but not open dwell time. Several studies emphasize the importance of aromatics in potential lipid interactions for MscL (Sawada et al., 2012) as well as other mechanosensitive channels such as TRPY1 and other TRP channels (Su et al., 2007; Zhou et al., 2007) and belts of aromatics are seen in other membrane proteins, including KcsA (Doyle et al., 1998). Thus, aromatic residue-lipid interactions may play more of  role in mechanosensation than kinetics. We also observed that there is no correlation between mechanosensitivity and open dwell time for the various substitutions. Hence, although the relative hydrophobicity of this spring element effects changes in both kinetics and mechanosensation, it does so by different underlying mechanisms. In summary, by initially using  chimera approach, we identified  single amino acid serves as   clasp knife spring  for the resistance and stability of channel opening and closing. The hydrophobicity and steric shape of this residue, complemented by the periplasmic loop, appears to define channel mechanosensitivity and kinetics in both Sa- and Eco-MscL. Yang et al. Experimental Procedures Strains and cell growth All chimeras were generated using the PCR ligation method (Blount and Krause, 1993; Innis et al., 1990). All other site-directed mutants were generated using Mega primer method as described previously (Levin and Blount, 2004) and all were inserted in the pB10d expression construct (Blount et al., 1996a; Ou et al., 1998). The . coli strain PB104 ( mscL:Cm) was used for electrophysiological experiments (Blount et al., 1996a; Ou et al., 1998). Cultures were grown routinely in Lennox broth (LB) medium (Fisher Scientific, Pittsburbh, PA, USA) containing 100  /ml ampicillin. Expression was induced by addition of  mM isopropyl- --thiogalactopyranoside (IPTG; Anatrace inc., Maumee, OH, USA). Electrophysiology As described previously (Blount et al., 1999; Martinac et al., 1987), excised, inside-out patches from . coli giant spheroplasts were examined at room temperature. Patch buffer contained 200 mM KCl, 90 mM MgCl2, 10 mM CaCl2, and  mM HEPES (Sigma, St. Louis, MO), pH .. Data were acquired at  20 mV at  sampling rate of 20 kHz with  - kHz filter, using an AxoPatch 200B amplifier in conjunction with Axoscope software (Axon Instruments, Union City, CA, USA). For simplicity, the channel openings are shown upwards in the figures. piezoelectric pressure transducer (World Precision Instruments, Sarasota, FL, USA) was used to monitor the pressure introduced to patch membrane by suction throughout the experiments. Measurements were performed using Clampfit9 from pCLAMP9 (Axon Instruments). For the kinetic experiments, the data were fit to  three open state model, as previously performed (Blount et al., 1996a; Blount et al., 1996b; Ou et al., 1998). The two longer time constants (  and  ) could be easily determined; the shortest is beyond the resolution of the equipment used. All kinetic data were obtained from at least 300 opening events per mutant from three independent experiments performed in at least two independent spheroplast preparations. Mechanosensitivity was determined as previously described (Blount et al., 1999; Blount et al., 1996a; Ou et al., 1998). Briefly, MscS is used as an internal standard within the patch, and the ratio of gating pressure for MscL divided by the threshold pressure of MscS is determined; here we will refer to this as the pL/pS ratio. All mechanosensitivity data were obtained from at least three independent recordings performed in at least two independent spheroplast preparations.
